bibl.title: Sacred Stories of the Sweet Grass Cree
bibl.series: National Museum of Canada, Bulletin no. 60, Anthropological Series, no. 11

encodingdesc.p: This electronic document is oriented more toward representing those features that seem most likely to be relevant for grammatical analyses, rather than toward faithfully representing all the information available in the book.

list.item: 2014 06 10; KR; UTF-8, paragraph and sentence numbering, smart-quotes in English translations

p.seg: kîtahtawê pêyak awa nâpêw kwah pêyak iskwêw , owîkimâkanah , nîsiwak . Once upon a time there were two people, a man and his wife. FIX (kwahpeyak -> kwah peyak)
kîtahtawê awâsisah ayâwêwak . Presently they had a child.
êkotê êkwah êh-ay-âyâcik , pisisik mâcîw awa nâpêw . There where they dwelt the man would always hunt.
piyisk wâpamêwak awâsisah , nâpêsis . And so, in the course of time, they had a child, a boy.
êkwah êkotah ay-ayâwak . They stayed in that place.
piyisk misikitiw awa nâpêsis . In time the boy grew big.
pôti miyosiw awa nâpêsis . He turned out handsome.
miywêyimêwak ; sâkihêwak okosisiwâwa . They loved him; they were fond of their son.
namoya kêkway atoskêw awa nâpêsis . They boy did not work at all.
tahkih miywâsiniyiwa otayôwinisa , ê-kaskikwâtahk aw iskwêw okosisah otayôwinisiyiwa . His clothes were always good, for the woman sewed her son's clothing.
êkosi piyisk oskinîkiw aw âwâsis . So in time the child became a young man.

êkwah awa oskinîkiw ômis îtwêw :
mahtih kakwê-nipah ocêk , itêw ôhtâwiya . Then that young man spoke as follows: “Pray, try to kill a fisher,” he said to his father.
miyâkîkih awa nâpêw wîh-kakwê-wâpamêw ocêkah . And so that man tried to get sight of a fisher. LB on {miyâkîkih}: Apparently a particle; meaning?
kîtahtawê wâpamêw ocêkah ; nipahêw . Presently he saw a fisher; he killed it.
êwakonih osîhêw aw ôskinîkiw . The youth prepared it.
êh-kîsihât , otastotiniw . When he had finished it, he wore it as a hat.
mîna acosisah ayâw , nikikwayânah êh-opîhtatwânit , êkotah êh-âsiwatêyikih owîpisisah aw ôskinîkiw . He had arrows, too, and used an otterskin for his quiver, to put his arrows in, that youth.
oskotâkay pahkêkin êh-pîmikitêyik ; otâsah mîna ê-pîmikitêyikih . His coat was a hide ornamented with quill-work; and his breeches, too, were worked with quills.
nama wîhkâc mâcîw . He never went hunting.

kîtahtawê ômis îtwêw :
nôhtâh , kiyânaw cî pikoh êh-ayîsiyiniwiyahk ? itêw . Then at one time he spoke thus: “Father, are we the only human beings there are?” he asked him.

seg.gloss: “No.
Everywhere are people.
But they are not good, they always contend.
When they defeat one another, they destroy each other; they are not good.”

p.seg:
kah ! itwêw aw oskinîkiw ;
mahtih nika-kakwê-wâpamâwak kotakak ayîsiyiniwak , itwêw aw oskinîkiw . “Just think of it!” said the yout; “I should like to try and see the other people,” said the youth.
mihtâtam awa kisêyiniw mîn âwa iskwêw , okosisiwâwa ê-sâkihâcik . The old man was sorry at this, and the old woman, for they cherished their son. FIX (awaiskwew -> awa iskwew)
mâskôc ta-misi-wanâcihôw , êh-itêyimât okosisiwâwa , mâtôw aw îskwêw . “Surely he will go to his undoing,” thought the woman of their son, and wept.
êkosi namoya kî-kitahamawêwak ê-wîh-sipwêhtêyit okosisiwâwa . And so they were not able to keep their son from going forth.
wâpahkih nika-sipwêhtân , itwêw aw oskinîkiw . “Tomorrow I shall go,” said the youth.

hêhêhêy ! itwêw awa nâpêw ;
nikosis , êkâ wiya âpihtaw-kîsikâhk isi itohtê ! itêw okosisah . “Dear me!” said the man; “My son, do not go in the direction of noon!” he told his son.
âhag , itwêw awa oskinîkiw . “Very well,” answered the youth.
tâpwê êh-wâpaniyik , sipwêhtêw aw oskinîkiw . Accordingly, when day broke, the youth departed.

omis îtwêw :
nôhtâh , nêkâ , nika-takosinin , êkâ misi-wanâtisiyâni . He said, “Father, mother, I shall come here, if I am not destroyed.
têpiyâhk ê-wîh-wâpamakik ayîsiyiniwak , itwêw aw ôskinîkiw , ê-postastotinêt . It is only that I want to see the people,” said the youth, as he put on his hat.

hâw , ocêkiwayânah k-ôtastotinit nitisiyihkâson , itwêw , êh-ati-wayawît . “Now then, Fisherskin-Hat is my name,” he said, as he stepped out of the house. LB hyphenates the name {ocêkiwayânah-k-ôtastotinit}
mâtôyiwa okâwiya , êh-atamiskâkot . His mother wept as she said farewell to him.
êkosi sipwêhtêw , êh-pimohtêt . So he set out and walked along.
kapê-kîsik pimohtêw , êkâ ê-pîsimowiyik itêhkêy isih êh-itohtêt . All day he walked, walking in the direction where there is no sun.
kîtahtawê êh-pimohtêt , êh-otâkosiniyik , kâ-wâpamât pihyêwah . Presently, as he walked along, in the evening, he saw a partridge.

pimwêw ; nipahêw ,
nika-môwâw , itah kapêsiyâni , êy-itêyihtah . He shot it and killed it, thinking, “I shall eat it when I camp for the night.”
êkosi êh-kîh-otinât , ati-pa-paskopitêw . So he took it and plucked it.
êy-âyapâskwêyâyik ê-pimohtêt , kîtahtawê kâ-wâpahtahk wîstêpahkwâyikamikos . As he walked by a place where there were clumps of trees, presently he saw a little lodge of smoked-up leather.

êkotah itohtêw ,
mahtih kêkway ôma itah êh-ayât ? êy-itêyihtah . He went there, thinking, “I wonder what sort of person stays there.”

êh-takohtêt skwahtêmihk ,
pîhtokê , nôsisimis ! k-êtwêt nôtokêsiw . When he reached the doorway, “Come in, grandchild!” said an old woman.
êh-pîhtokêt , pôt ôhi kî-pêyakoyiwa . When he went in, there she was, all by herself.

ta-tawâw ! itwêyiwa ;
nêhê ohc-âpi , itik . “Come in!” she said; “Sit over there!” she told him. CHECK nêhê: nêtê? nâhâ?
ôhi pihêwah kâ-tahkonât miyêw ôhkoma . He gave his grandmother the partridge he was holding.
kitatamihin , nôsisimis ; êkotôwahk nnôhtê-môwâ ! itwêyiwah . Thank you, my grandchild; this is exactly what I was wanting to eat!” she said.

êkosi êkwah ômis îtik :
nôsisimis , âyiman ôma itê k-êtohtêyin . Then she told him thus: “Grandchild, it is a hard place to which you are going.

seg.gloss: It would be better if you went home tomorrow.

p.seg: âyimisiwak ôma ayîsiyiniwak , itik ôhkoma . Hard to deal with are the people there,” his grandmother told him.
namoya , nôhkô ; osâm âsay nipê-sipwêhtân , itêw . “No, grandmother; for now I have already set out this way,” he answered her.

kah ! itik ;
awahê mâka , nôsisê ! itik . “Dear me!” she said to him; “Then be careful, grandson!”
tâpwêw paminawasôyiwa , pêyak mînis êh-pakâhtâyit êkwah pêyak cîsâwânis . And so she set about cooking a meal, putting in the pot a single berry and a single bit of chopped meat.

ê-kitâpamât ,
kêhcinâ namoya nika-kîspon ! itêyihtam . When he observed her, “Surely I shall not eat my fill!” he thought.

ômis îtwêw awa nôtokêsiw :
nôsisimis , kika-kîspon ôma , itêw . Thus spoke his grandmother; “My grandchild, you will eat your fill of this,” she told him.

yahê ! itêyihtam aw oskinîkiw ,
namoy êcik âwa kê-kî-mâ-mitonêyimak ! itêyihtam . “Goodness me!” thought the youth, “Plainly, I shall not be able to think about her!” he thought. FIX (ecikawa -> ecik awa)
êhag , nôsisimis ! katât cî ka-mâ-mitonêyimin ? itik . “No, my grandchild! Why should you have to think about me?” she said to him.
kiskêyihtamiyiwa êh-mâ-mitonêyimât . She knew that he had taken her as his object of meditation.
êkosi êkwah asamik ; êkos îsi pakitinamâk otaskihkoyiwa . So then she gave him to eat; she gave him her cooking-pot, just as it was.

êkwah êh-mîcisot , kahkiyaw mâna êh-otinahk , ê-saskamot , êtâpicih askihkosihk , kêyâpic nîso kiy-astêyiwa . As he ate, whenever he took up the whole contents and put it into his mouth, when he looked at the little pot, there lay the two morsels again.
piyisk âhkamêyimôw êh-mîcisot . At last he ate all the faster.
piyisk kîspôw ; namoya kîh-kitâw ôhi k-âsamikot ôhkomah . At last he had enough; he was not able to eat up the things his grandmother had given him to eat.
itisinamawêw . He handed it back to her.
namoya nikîh-kitân , nôhkô , itêw . “I cannot finish it, grandmother,” he said to her.

nah , nôsisimis tâpwê êh-îkicikâwit êh-mîcisot , êkâ kâ-kîh-kitât nimînisimah , nikîsitêpôwinah ! itik . “Dear me, truly my grandchild merely pecks at his food, seeing that he cannot finish my little berries, my bits of cooked meat!” she said to him.
piyisk mistahi tipiskâyiw . By now it was deep night.
nôsisê , kinêstohtâ ; kawisimoh , itik . “Grandson, you must be tired from walking; like down,” she told him.
kawisimôw ; wîsta kawisimôw awa nôtokêsiw . He lay down; the old woman, too, lay down.
êkosi êh-wâpaniyik , ê-waniskâcik , mina mîcisôwak . When dawn came, when they got up, they ate again.

ê-kîsi-mîcisocik ,
â , nôsisê , êkây ôm ôtah êh-ohci-sâkâstêk , êkây îtohtê ! When they had eaten, “Now then, grandson, do not go in this direction whence comes the morning light!
âyimisiw êkotah êh-ayât , itik ; Hard to deal with is he who dwells there,” she told him;
ôtêy isi nâtakâm is îtohtê , itik . “Go this way, toward the north,” she told him.
êhag , itwêw , êh-sipwêhtêt , êh-pimohtêt . “Very well,” said he, as he departed and continued his journey.

wâhyaw êh-ihtât ,
mahtih tânêhk ôma k-ôh-kitahamawit nôhkom ? itêyihtam . When he had gone a long ways, “I wonder why my grandmother warned me away from this place?” he thought.
êkotê isi waskîw . He turned in that direction.
kîtahtawê , kêkâc êh-âpihtaw-kîsikâyik , kâ-wâpamât ayîsiyiniwah ispatinâhk êh-apiyit . Presently, when it was almost noon, he saw someone sitting on a knoll.
ohpimêh êkotah wîh-at-îtohtêw , êh-pasikôwit , êkotê k-êsi-waskît . He was going to walk on, leaving the place to one side, when the other arose, in the very direction toward which he had turned.
êk ât êh-wîh-itohtêt , mâka êkotê isi ispayiw . Although he tried not to go there, yet he landed in that direction.
piyisk âmaciwêw , êh-wâpamât . At last he went up the hill where he saw the other.

pôt ôhi mistahi mâyâtisiyiwa ayîsiyiniwa , êh-mâskâwikanêyit , êh-âpisîsisiyit , maskwayânah êh-kikasâkêyit , There he saw that that man was very ugly, hunchbacked and small, and clad in a bearskin coat; FIX (êh-kikaskâkêyit -> êh-kikasâkêyit,)

êh-pêh-nâtikot , kontah ê-pêy-ostostotamiyit omis êh-itikot :
ocêkiwayânah k-ôtastotinit , mâna kipê-mêtawâ ! itik ; this man came to meet him, and as he came, had a fit of coughing, and said to him: “Fisherskin-Hat, you always were coming here to play!” he told him; LB hyphenates the name {ocêkiwayânah-k-ôtastotinit}

seg.gloss: “Of old, ‘He will go about engaging in contests,’ was said of you, you know!”

p.seg: namoya ê-papâ-mêtâwêyân , itêw . “It is not going about to engage in contests I am,” he told him.
hâ , namoya ! pikoh ka-mêtawêyahk ! itik . “Oh, don't say that! Only do let us have a contest!” the other said to him.
namoya ! itêw . “No!” he answered him.

seg.q: îh nêma kâ-sakâk kiwâpahtên cî kâ-pikihtêk ?
seg.gloss: “Do you see that clump of trees right over there, where the smoke is rising?”
“Yes!”

seg.q: mistah ânik êkotah ê-miyosicik oskinîkiskwêwak nîso êh-ayâcik .
seg.gloss: “Very beautiful are the two young women who live there.

p.seg: êyôkonik kik-âstwâtonânaw , itik . They will be the prize,” the other told him.
â , namoya ! itêw . “Oh, no!” he said to him.
â , kiyâm mâsihitotân ! itik . “Oh, please do let us wrestle!” the other said to him.

piyis ,
êhag , itêw . At last he said, “Yes,” to him.
êkwah astâw otakohp minah owîpisisah ; kahkiyaw otayôwinisah ; otastotinah pikoh namoy âhyêw . Then he put down his blanket-robe and his arrows, and all his clothes; only his hat he did not put down.
hâ , kitastotin mîna ahih , itik . “Ho, set down your hat, too,” the other told him.

seg.gloss: “Oh dear, no!”

p.seg: êkos îsi mâsihitôwak . So then they wrestled.
namoya kîh-sâkohêw . He could not overcome him.
mwêhcih êh-nayawapit , âcikêwêpahwêw ; kawiwêpinêw . At last, just as he was getting out of breath, he tripped the other and threw him; he got him down.

seg.q: âh , ocêkiwayânah k-ôtastotinit , nipisohên kiskât , k-ô-sâkohiyin .
seg.gloss: “Ho, Fisherskin-Hat, I stumbled over your leg, that is why you have got the better of me.

p.seg: pêyakwâw ! itik . Once more!” the other said to him.
â , namoya ! âsay kisâkohitin , itêw . “Oh no! I have beaten you now,” he answered the other.

seg.gloss: “No; once more!”
“Very well!”

p.seg: mâsihitôwak . They wrestled.
êh-mêkwâ-mâsihitocik , kwâskwêwêpinêyiwa otastotinah . While they were at grips, the other knocked his his hat up into the air.
êkosi êkwah sâkohik ; kaskâwikanênik , ê-sâposkâkot , ê-maskamikot omiyosiwin . Thereupon the other overcame him; he broke his back and entered his body, taking away his good looks.
kâ-kî-wâpamât êy-isinâkosiyit , êkos îsinâkosiw aw oskinîkiw . As he had seen the other to look, such was now the appearance of that youth.
êkoh ôhi kâh-mâyâtisiyit miyosiyiwa . And that other, who had been ugly, was now handsome.

êh-kitâpamât ,
mistahi pikô oma êh-miyosiyân , kâ-kîsinâcihit , ê-maskamit nimiyosiwin ! itêyihtam . When he looked at him, “Greatly has he injured me as to my good looks, robbing me thus of my beauty!” thought he.
otayôwinisah otinamiyiwa , ê-postayôwinisêyit , otastotinah mîna . The other took his clothes and put them on, and his hat as well.
êkonih anih kitayôwinisah , maskwayânêtâs ! itik . “These here are your clothes, Bearskin-Breeches!” the other told him.
otayôwinisiyiwa êkwah postayôwinisêw . Then he put on the other's clothes.
wiyaskoc êkwa pisisik ostostotam . And now he, instead of the other, was incessantly coughing.
ayisk namoya tâpwêhtam kâ-kîh-itikot ôhkomah . Well, he had not followed his grandmother's advice.
hâw , maskwayânêtês , ntawi-wîwitân ! itik . “Well now, Bearskin-Breeches, let us go take our wives!” the other told him.
tâpwê sipwêhtêwak , êh-itohtêcik ôh ôskinîkiskwêwah . So they set out to go to those young women.
cîk êh-îhtâcik , kâ-pê-wayawiyit ôh ôskinîkiskwêwah . When they were near the place, out came the elder sister.

seg.gloss: Here are these young men coming!”

p.seg: êh-wayawît ôw ôskinîkiskwêw , kâ-wâpamât êh-pêcâstamohtêyit . When that young woman came out, there she saw them walking up.

seg.gloss: “Come, little sister, let us see who gets there first!

p.seg: awiyak nakasiwêcih , anihi kâ-miyosiyit kit-onâpêmiw , itwêw aw ômisimâw . Whichever runs the faster, let her have the handsome one for her husband,” said the elder sister.
êhag , itwêw aw ôsîmimâw . “Very well,” said the younger.
wayacâwiwak ôk îskwêwak . The woman started to run.
mwêhcih wâh-nakatikocih osîmisa , otihtinêw êh-asêwêpinât ; Whenever her younger sister was about to pass her, she seized hold of her and flung her back;

piyisk aw ômisimâw ôhi kâ-miyosiyit oskinîkiwah nawatinêw ,
awa niya nika-wîkimâw ! êh-itwêt . in the end that elder sister grabbed hold of the handsome youth saying, “This one I shall wed!”
mâka aw ôskinîkiskwêw osîmimâw êyako miyosiw . But it was the younger woman who was handsome.

êkwah ,
na kinâpêm ! itâw aw ôsîmâw , ôhi kâ-mâskâwikanêyit k-ôstostotaskêyit . Then, “There's your husband!” they said to the younger one, pointing to the hunchback who had a cough.
kîwêhtahêwak . They took the men home with them.
êh-pîhtokêcik , awa k-ostostotaskêt nêtê iskwâhtêmihk êkotah nahapiw . When they entered the lodge, the one who had the cough took his seat yonder by the doorway.
awâ wiya kâ-miyosit oskinîkiw tahk êh-âkwaskitiniht , êh-ocêmikot owîkimâkana , mistahi miywêyihtam . But the handsome youth, whose wife kept hugging and kissing him, thought it very fine.
êkotah ayâwak , mînisah pikoh êh-mîcicik ôk îskwêwak . There they dwelt, and those women had only berries to eat.
piyisk tipiskâyiw , êh-apicik . At last night came, as they sat there.
iyikohk ê-kawisimocik , pêyakohkwâmiw awa kâ-mâskâwikanêt . [no translation]
piyis wâpaniyiw . Morning came.
êh-wâpahk , kîkisêpâ êh-waniskâcik , êh-kîh-mîcisotik , wawêyîw , ê-wîh-mâcît awa kâ-miyosit . In the morning, when they got up, when they had eaten, the handsome one went out to go hunting.
ê-wîh-ati-wayawît , tahkiskawêw ôhi ka-mâskâwikanêyit . On his way out, he kicked the hunchback.

seg.gloss: “Why are you sitting like that, Bearskin-Breeches? Didn't you know we were staying at our wives'?”

p.seg: êh-ati-wayawît , kîpiwêpiskawêw , kontah êh-ostostotamipayiyit . On his way out he upset him with a kick, so that he reeled about and coughed.

êkosi êh-waniskât , omis îtêw :
pêtâ pîsâkanâpiy , itêw ôhô owîkimâkana . When he arose, he said to his wife, “Bring me a rawhide rope.”
miyik pîsâkanâpîs . She gave him a little leather thong.
êkos âti-wayawîw , êh-at-ôstostotahk , wîst êh-mâcît . Thereupon he left the house, coughing as he went, to go a-hunting, he too.
kêkway êtokê kê-nipahtât ! itêw aw ômisimâw wîtimwa . “I can't imagine what he will kill!” said the older sister of her brother-in-law.
êkosi êkwah kapê-kîsik mâcîwak . So all day they hunted.
êh-otâkosiniyik , takosin awa kâ-miyosit . At nightfall the handsome man arrived.
pôtih âpohtêw nikikwah pêyak . His booty turned out to be one otter.
êkosi namoya takosin awa k-ôstostotaskêt . Meanwhile he who had the cough did not arrive.

piyis êh-tipiskâyik ,
namoya ciw oyâ kôh-wâpamâw nântaw ? itêw onâpêma . At last, when it was dark, “Did you not see him anywhere?” the one asked her husband.

seg.gloss: “No; I did not see him at all.

p.seg: tântê kê-kawacikwê ! itêw , ayisk êh-piponiyik . I daresay he will be freezing to death somewhere!” he answered her, for it was winter-time.
kîtahtawê kâ-pê-saskahohtêyit , êh-pê-takohtêyit . After some time, there came the other, leaning on a stick; at last he arrived.
nî , mînah têkohtêt ! itwêw awa omisimâw . “Why, he really has come!” said the elder sister.
êh-pê-pîhtokêt , êkotah iskwâhtêmihk nahapiw , êh-itisinamawât pîsâkanâpiy ôh ôwîkimâkanah . When he entered, he took his seat there by the door, and handed his wife the rawhide.
êh-ocipitahk aw ôskinîkiskwêw , kâ-pê-pîhtokêpitât pêyak paspaskiwa pihyêwa . When the young woman pulled at it, in she pulled a partridge or a prairie-chicken.

ômisi kih-itwêw aw ômisimâw , onâpêma êh-pêsiwâyit nikikwa :
nisîmis , namoya kik-âsahtonânaw . This was what the elder sister had said, when her husband brought the otter: “Sister, we shall not invite each other to eat.

kiwîkimâkaninawak êy-isi-nipahâcik , ka-môwânawak , itêw osîma ,
namoya ta-kih-nipahtâw kêkway , êh-itêyimât osîmah owîkimâkaniyiwa . Whatever our husbands kill we shall eat,” she had told her sister, for she thought that her sister's husband would not succeed in killing anything.
êkosi tâpwê namoy âsahtôwak , ôki kâ-miyosit awa nikikwa êh-môwâcik . So now, accordingly, they did not share their food, but the handsome man and his wife ate the otter.
êkwah awa osîmimâw paspaskiwa môwêwak . And the younger sister and her husband ate the partridge.
êkosi piyis kawisimôwak . So in time they went to bed.
kêyâpic pêyakohkwâmiw awa maskwayânêtâs . [no translation] [Still Bearskin Breeches slept alone.]

iyikohk mîna êh-wâpaniyik , kîksêpâ êh-waniskâcik , âsay mîna wayawîw , êh-mâcît awa kâ-miyosit , âsay mina tahkiskawêw . And again, when day broke and they got up, the handsome man went out to hunt. Again he kicked the other. FIX (eh-macitawa -> eh-macit awa)

seg.gloss: “Why are you sitting like that?

p.seg: kôskiskwêwâhtânaw , maskwayânêtâs ! itêw , êh-kîpiwêpiskawât , tâpiskôc ta-nipiyit , iyikohk êy-ostostotamiyit , konta mâna mistah êh-pâhpit aw ômisimâw , wîtimwa kiyîpiwêpiskâmihcih . Didn't you know we were newly married, Bearskin-Breeches?” he said to him, kicking him over, so that he coughed as if he were going to die, the elder sister meanwhile laughing and laughing at her brother-in-law being kicked about. resegmented 18.85.1-2 FIX (êy-ostostotamiyt -> êy-ostostotamiyit)
âsay mîn êyakô sipwêhtêw , êh-mâcît . The latter, too, went off to hunt.
êyakô kapê-kîsik papâmohtêw . All that day he tramped about.
iyikohk êh-otâkosik , âsay mîna takohtêw awa kâ-miyosit ; asay mîna nikikwah pêsiwêw . When night fell, again the handsome man arrived; again he brought an otter.
